newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria's NNPC wins insurance case on appeal.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria's NNPC wins insurance case on appeal.

text.p: State-owned Nigerian National Petroleum Corp (NNPC) on Thursday won its appeal against a lower court order that it should insure its assets with state insurance firm NICON, the News Agency of Nigeria reported.
It said the three-member federal court of appeal unanimously decided to reverse the decision of the high court in January that "NICON should insure and re-insure NNPC assets for 1997."
The judges said the lower court was in no position to force NNPC to insure its assets with any particular firm.
At stake is NNPC's move to transfer its account, worth 2.025 billion naira, to other insurance firms.
Six Nigerian firms went to court last November to contest who should control NNPC's lucrative insurance account.
NNPC, 100 percent owned by the federal government, pumps two million barrels of crude oil daily, which accounts for more than 90 percent of Nigeria's foreign exchange earnings.
Its assets include oil refineries, petrochemical plants, oil depots and sundry other properties.

Two of the feuding firms -- Fidelity Bond of Nigeria and Trinity Mills Insurance Brokers -- had urged the lower court to stop the transfer of the account from NICON to the four other firms -- UNIC Insurance, Industrial and General Insurance Company Limited, Inter-Continental Insurance Company Limited and Kapital Insurance Company Nigeria Limited.
All six companies are 100 percent Nigerian-owned.
National Insurance Corporation of Nigeria (NICON), Nigeria's biggest insurance firm is 100 percent federal government-owned and usually insures the properties of state agencies.
